definition: to start over from scratch (idiom)
heavy/serious/to attach importance to
to repeat/repetition/again/re-/classifier: layer

to rise/to raise/to get up/to set out/to start/to appear/to launch/to initiate (action)/to draft/to establish/to get (from a depot or counter)/verb suffix, to start/starting from (a time, place, price etc)/classifier for occurrences or unpredictable events: case, instance/classifier for groups: batch, group
stove/furnace

kitchen stove/kitchen
variant of 灶[zao4]
lit. to set up a separate kitchen (idiom); to start from scratch/back to square one/to start of on a new path
to adjust one's head and turn one's face (idiom); cosmetic changes/Despite superficially new policies, the substance remains unchanged.
change of string, move out of rut (idiom); dramatic change of direction/to dance to a different tune
to form one's own group or school of thought/to set up one's own business/to establish oneself
to live apart from parents (of married couple)/to achieve independence
to cherish the outmoded and preserve the outworn (idiom); conservative/stickler for tradition
to take an alternate route (idiom)/to find an alternative/to take a different approach/to blaze a new trail
lit. to reorganize flags and drums (idiom); to regroup after a setback/to prepare for new initiatives/to attempt a comeback
to resume one's old trade (idiom)
to improve one's family's social status by moving up in the world/to switch one's allegiance to a new patron
bold and decisive
to close down a business for good and put the best face on it (idiom)
lit. to return to office after living as a hermit on Mount Dongshan (idiom); fig. to make a comeback
to make painstaking efforts (idiom); after much trouble/to work hard at sth
to build up an enterprise through painstaking efforts
to totally stop doing something/to reform one's ways
